K(L(G,H),F)}function f(G,F,aa,Z,k,H,I){G=K(G,K(K(q(F,aa,Z),k),I));return K(L(G,H),F)}function D(G,F,aa,Z,k,H,I){G=K(G,K(K(p(F,aa,Z),k),I));return K(L(G,H),F)}function t(G,F,aa,Z,k,H,I){G=K(G,K(K(n(F,aa,Z),k),I));return K(L(G,H),F)}function e(G){var Z;var F=G.length;var x=F+8;var k=(x-(x%64))/64;var I=(k+1)*16;var aa=Array(I-1);var d=0;var H=0;while(H<F){Z=(H-(H%4))/4;d=(H%4)*8;aa[Z]=(aa[Z]| (G.charCodeAt(H)<<d));H++}Z=(H-(H%4))/4;d=(H%4)*8;aa[Z]=aa[Z]|(128<<d);aa[I-2]=F<<3;aa[I-1]=F>>>29;return aa}function B(x){var k="",F="",G,d;for(d=0;d<=3;d++){G=(x>>>(d*8))&255;F="0"+G.toString(16);k=k+F.substr(F.length-2,2)}return k}function J(k){k=k.replace(/rn/g,"n");var d="";for(var F=0;F<k.length;F++){var x=k.charCodeAt(F);if(x<128){d+=String.fromCharCode(x)}else{if((x>127)&&(x<2048)){d+=String.fromCharCode((x>>6)|192);d+=String.fromCharCode((x&63)|128)}else{d+=String.fromCharCode((x>>12)|224);d+=String.fromCharCode(((x>>6)&63)|128);d+=String.fromCharCode((x&63)|128)}}}return d}var C=Array();var P,h,E,v,g,Y,X,W,V;var S=7,Q=12,N=17,M=22;var A=5,z=9,y=14,w=20;var o=4,m=11,l=16,j=23;var U=6,T=10,R=15,O=21;s=J(s);C=e(s);Y=1732584193;X=4023233417;W=2562383102;V=271733878;for(P=0;P<C.length;P+=16){h=Y;E=X;v=W;g=V;Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+0],S,3614090360);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+1],Q,3905402710);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+2],N,606105819);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+3],M,3250441966);Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+4],S,4118548399);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+5],Q,1200080426);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+6],N,2821735955);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+7],M,4249261313);Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+8],S,1770035416);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+9],Q,2336552879);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+10],N,4294925233);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+11],M,2304563134);Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+12],S,1804603682);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+13],Q,4254626195);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+14],N,2792965006);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+15],M,1236535329);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+1],A,4129170786);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+6],z,3225465664);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+11],y,643717713);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+0],w,3921069994);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+5],A,3593408605);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+10],z,38016083);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+15],y,3634488961);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+4],w,3889429448);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+9],A,568446438);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+14],z,3275163606);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+3],y,4107603335);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+8],w,1163531501);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+13],A,2850285829);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+2],z,4243563512);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+7],y,1735328473);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+12],w,2368359562);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+5],o,4294588738);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+8],m,2272392833);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+11],l,1839030562);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+14],j,4259657740);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+1],o,2763975236);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+4],m,1272893353);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+7],l,4139469664);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+10],j,3200236656);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+13],o,681279174);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+0],m,3936430074);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+3],l,3572445317);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+6],j,76029189);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+9],o,3654602809);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+12],m,3873151461);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+15],l,530742520);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+2],j,3299628645);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+0],U,4096336452);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+7],T,1126891415);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+14],R,2878612391);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+5],O,4237533241);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+12],U,1700485571);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+3],T,2399980690);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+10],R,4293915773);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+1],O,2240044497);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+8],U,1873313359);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+15],T,4264355552);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+6],R,2734768916);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+13],O,1309151649);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+4],U,4149444226);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+11],T,3174756917);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+2],R,718787259);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+9],O,3951481745);Y=K(Y,h);X=K(X,E);W=K(W,v);V=K(V,g)}var i=B(Y)+B(X)+B(W)+B(V);return i.toLowerCase()}
    ,stripProductDelimiters: function(val) {
        if (val) {
            return val.replace(/\;|\||\,/gi, '-');
        }
    }

    ,setCookie: function(name, value, seconds, domain) {
        domain = document.location.hostname;
        var expires = '';
        var expiresNow = '';
        var date = new Date();
        date.setTime(date.getTime() + (-1 * 1000));
        expiresNow = "; expires=" + date.toGMTString();

        if (typeof(seconds) != 'undefined') {
            date.setTime(date.getTime() + (seconds * 1000));
            expires = '; expires=' + date.toGMTString();
        }

        var type = typeof(value);
        type = type.toLowerCase();
        if (type != 'undefined' && type != 'string') {
            value = JSON.stringify(value);
        }

        // fix scoping issues
        // keep writing the old cookie, but make it expire
        document.cookie = name + '=' + value + expiresNow + '; path=/';

        // now just set the right one
        document.cookie = name + '=' + value + expires + '; path=/; domain=' + domain;
    }

    ,getCookie: function(name) {
        name = name + '=';
        var carray = document.cookie.split(';'), value;

        for (var i=0; i<carray.length; i++) {
            var c = carray[i];
            while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
                c = c.substring(1, c.length);
            }
            if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
                value = c.substring(name.length, c.length);
                try {
                    value = JSON.parse(value);
                } catch(ex) {}

                return value;
            }
        }

        return null;
    }

    ,deleteCookie: function(name) {
        this.setCookie(name, '', -1);
        this.setCookie(name, '', -1, document.location.hostname);
    }

    ,mapAdobeVars: function(s) {
        var vars = {
            pageName		: 'Page - Analytics Pagename'
            ,channel		: 'Page - Section Name'
            ,campaign		: 'Campaign - ID'
            ,currencyCode	: 'Page - Currency Code'
            ,purchaseID		: 'Order - ID'
            ,prop1			: 'Visitor - Account ID'
            ,prop2			: 'Page - Product Name'
            ,prop4			: 'Page - Type'
            ,prop6			: 'Search - Type'
            ,prop7			: 'Search - Facet List'
            ,prop8			: 'Search - Feature Used'
            ,prop12			: 'Visitor - User ID'
            ,prop13			: 'Search - Sort Type'
            ,prop14			: 'Page - Load Time'
            ,prop15         : 'Support - Topic Name'
            ,prop16			: 'Page - Business Unit'
            ,prop21			: 'Search - Criteria'
            ,prop24			: 'Page - Language'
            ,prop25			: 'Page - Product Feature'
            ,prop28         : 'Support - Search Criteria'
            ,prop30			: 'Visitor - IP Address'
            ,prop33         : 'Page - Product Application Version'
            ,prop34         : 'Page - Website Extensions'
            ,prop60			: 'Search - Data Form Criteria'
            ,prop63			: 'Page - Extended Page Name'
            ,prop65         : 'Page - Online State'
            ,prop67         : 'Research Networks'
            ,prop40: 'Page - UX Properties'

            ,eVar3			: 'Search - Total Results'
            ,eVar7			: 'Visitor - Account Name'
            ,eVar15			: 'Event - Search Results Click Position'
            ,eVar19			: 'Search - Advanced Criteria'
            ,eVar21			: 'Promo - Clicked ID'

        };

        for (var i in vars) {
            s[i] = s[i] ? s[i] : _satellite.getVar(vars[i]);
        }
    }
};

// async support fallback
(function(w) {
	var eventBuffer = [];
	if(w.appData) {
		if(Array.isArray(w.appData)) {
			eventBuffer = w.appData;
		} else {
			console.error('Elsevier DataLayer "window.appData" must be specified as array');
			return;
		}
    }

	w.appData = [];

	var oldPush = w.appData.push;

	var appDataPush = function() {
        oldPush.apply(w.appData, arguments);
        for(var i=0; i<arguments.length; i++) {
            var data = arguments[i];
            if(data.event) {
                if(data.event == 'pageLoad') {
                    w.pageDataTracker.trackPageLoad(data);
                } else {
                    w.pageDataTracker.trackEvent(data.event, data);
                }
            }
        }
	};

	w.appData.push = appDataPush;
	for(var i=0; i<eventBuffer.length; i++) {
	    var data = eventBuffer[i];
	    w.appData.push(data);
	}
})(window);

</script><script>_satellite["_runScript1"](function(event, target, Promise) {
_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: clearing tracking state");try{s.events="",s.linkTrackVars="",s.linkTrackEvents=""}catch(e){_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: s object - could not reset state.")}try{dispatcherData=JSON.parse(event.detail),window.ddqueue=window.ddqueue||[],window.ddqueue.push(dispatcherData),window.eventData=dispatcherData.eventData,window.pageData=dispatcherData.pageData,_satellite.track(dispatcherData.eventName)}catch(e){_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: exception"),_satellite.logger.log(e)}
});</script><script>_satellite["_runScript2"](function(event, target, Promise) {

<script type="text/javascript">
        window.__PRELOADED_STATE__ = {"abstracts":{"content":[{"$$":[{"$":{"id":"cesectitle0001"},"#name":"section-title","_":"Abstract"},{"$$":[{"$$":[{"#name":"__text__","_":"Transition metal sulfides (TMSs) are regarded as one of the ideal anodes for sodium ion batteries (SIBs) owing to their high theoretical capacity and strong electrochemical activity; nonetheless, it still faces challenges such as large volume variation and low conductivity during chemical reactions for applications. Herein, the nanocubes of carbon-encapsulated NiS"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"/CoS"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" embedded porous nitrogen-doped carbon matrixes (NiS"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"/CoS"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"@NC@C) are synthesized as a high-performance anode by in-situ carbonizing and subsequently sulphurating the resorcinol-formaldehyde (RF)-coated Ni-Co-based Prussian blue analogues (PBAs). The RF-derived carbon shell acts as a rigid skeleton to effectively relieve the bulk stress during charging and discharging for ensuring the structure integrity, while the porous nitrogen-doped carbon matrix improves the electronic conductivity, presents rich channels for ion/electron transfer and inhibits the agglomeration of active material during chemical reaction. In addition, the lattice distortion at the heterogeneous interface of the NiS"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"/CoS"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" allows the redistribution of electrons, promoting the chemical reaction kinetics. Consequently, the NiS"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"/CoS"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"@NC@C nanocubes exhibit excellent electrochemical properties: a high discharge capacity of 489.9 mA h g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"−1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" after 170 cycles at 1.0 A g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"−1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" (920.6/807.9 mA h g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"−1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" for the initial discharge/charge capacity with the initial coulomb efficiency of 87.7%) and a discharge capacity of 349.7 mA h g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"−1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" with the CE close to 100.0% at 5.0 A g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"−1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" even after 2000 cycles. This study proposes a viable approach for the effective construction of advanced anodes with unique micromorphology and chemical composition based on bimetallic PBAs for SIBs."}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"spara006"},"#name":"simple-para"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"abss0001"},"#name":"abstract-sec"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"abs0001","class":"author"},"#name":"abstract"}],"floats":[],"footnotes":[],"attachments":[]},"accessbarConfig":{"fallback":false,"id":"accessbar","version":"0.0.1","analytics":{"location":"accessbar","eventName":"ctaImpression"},"label":{},"ariaLabel":{"accessbar":"Download options and search","componentsList":"PDF Options"},"banners":[{"id":"BannerSsrn"}],"components":[{"target":"_blank","analytics":[{"ids":["accessbar:fta:single-article"],"eventName":"ctaClick"}],"label":"View&nbsp;**PDF**","ariaLabel":"View PDF. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. href="/journal/electrochimica-acta/vol/469/suppl/C"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><img class="publication-cover-image" src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623X00292-cov150h.gif" alt="Electrochimica Acta"></span></span></a></div></div><h1 id="screen-reader-main-title" class="Head u-font-serif u-h2 u-margin-s-ver"><span class="title-text">NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C nanocubes derived from prussian blue analogues as an advanced anode with extraordinary long-cycle performance for sodium ion batteries</span></h1><div class="Banner" id="banner"><div class="wrapper truncated"><div aria-live="polite"></div><div class="AuthorGroups"><div class="author-group" id="author-group"><span class="sr-only">Author links open overlay panel</span><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-underline" type="button" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" class="given-name">Ransha</span> <span class="text surname">Deng</span></span></span></span></button>, <button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-underline" type="button" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="author" data-xocs-content-id="au0002"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text"><span class="react-xocs-alternative-link"><span class="given-name">Peng</span> <span class="text surname">Wang</span></span></span></span></button>, <button class="button-link button-link-secondary 22-22-9.86-22-22-22z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Share</span></span></button></div></div></div><div class="ExportCitation u-display-inline-block" id="export-citation"><div class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 104 128" height="20" class="icon 32z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.electacta.2023.143245" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.electacta.2023.143245</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S0013468623014172&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author" id="abs0001"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abss0001"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara006"><span>Transition metal sulfides (TMSs) are regarded as one of the ideal anodes for <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about sodium ion batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion batteries</a> (SIBs) owing to their high theoretical capacity and strong electrochemical activity; nonetheless, it still faces challenges such as large volume variation and low conductivity during chemical reactions for applications. Herein, the nanocubes of carbon-encapsulated NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub> embedded porous nitrogen-doped carbon matrixes (NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C) are synthesized as a high-performance anode by in-situ carbonizing and subsequently sulphurating the resorcinol-formaldehyde (RF)-coated Ni-Co-based Prussian blue analogues (PBAs). The RF-derived carbon shell acts as a rigid skeleton to effectively relieve the bulk stress during charging and discharging for ensuring the structure integrity, while the porous nitrogen-doped carbon matrix improves the electronic conductivity, presents rich channels for ion/electron transfer and inhibits the agglomeration of active material during chemical reaction. In addition, the lattice distortion at the heterogeneous interface of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub> allows the redistribution of electrons, promoting the chemical reaction kinetics. Consequently, the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub><span>@NC@C nanocubes exhibit excellent <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a>: a high discharge capacity of 489.9 mA h g</span><sup>−1</sup> after 170 cycles at 1.0 A g<sup>−1</sup> (920.6/807.9 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> for the initial discharge/charge capacity with the initial coulomb efficiency of 87.7%) and a discharge capacity of 349.7 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> with the CE close to 100.0% at 5.0 A g<sup>−1</sup> even after 2000 cycles. This study proposes a viable approach for the effective construction of advanced anodes with unique micromorphology and chemical composition based on bimetallic PBAs for SIBs.</div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0013468623014020"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0013468623014226"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="keys0001" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="key0001" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0002">Sodium ion batteries</span></div><div id="key0002" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0003">Transition metal sulfide</span></div><div id="key0003" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0004">Prussian blue analogue</span></div><div id="key0004" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0005">Nanocubes</span></div><div id="key0005" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0006">Heterogeneous interface</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0004" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0002"><span>In recent years, the high <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> and long cycle life of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have made them a popular choice for commercial energy storage devices </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0001" name="bbib0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0002" name="bbib0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0003" name="bbib0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0004" name="bbib0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>. However, the scarcity and geographically uneven dispersion of lithium resources hinder the further sustainable development of LIBs for large-scale energy storage <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0005" name="bbib0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0007" name="bbib0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0008" name="bbib0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a><span>. Hence, <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about sodium ion batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion batteries</a><span> (SIBs) have emerged with the times as the most promising alternative to LIBs owing to the advantages of abundant <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span> resources, low cost and high <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/oxidation-reduction-potential" title="Learn more about redox potential from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox potential</a> (-2.70 V </span></span></span><em>vs</em> SHE) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0009" name="bbib0009" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0009"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>. Unfortunately, most of the anodes for SIBs generally exhibit slow reaction kinetics and severe volume changes during charging and discharging due to much larger ionic radius (1.02 <em>vs</em> 0.76 Å) and molar mass (22.99 <em>vs</em> 6.94 g mol<sup>−1</sup>) of sodium than lithium <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0010" name="bbib0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0011" name="bbib0011" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0011"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0012" name="bbib0012" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0012"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a><span>, leading to weak electrochemical activity and poor <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a>. Obviously, designing anodes with large capacity and extended cycle life is crucial to the successful development of SIBs.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0003">Among various anodes for SIBs, conversion-type transition metal sulfides (TMSs) have received extensive attention due to their high theoretical capacities <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>. Specially, cobalt sulfide (CoS<sub>2</sub>) has been perceived as a promising anode owing to its much higher theoretical capacity (872 mA h g<sup>−1</sup>) than other sulfides <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>. However, the CoS<sub>2</sub>-based anodes still face challenges of poor conductivity, slow ion diffusion kinetics and poor structure stability, inevitably leading to large discrepancies between actual capacity and theoretical value <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0015" name="bbib0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>. Several effective strategies such as compounding with carbon materials <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0016" name="bbib0016" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0016"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0017" name="bbib0017" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0017"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a> and micro-nanostructure construction [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0019" name="bbib0019" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0019"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0020" name="bbib0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>] have been adopted to solve the above problems. For example, Li et&nbsp;al. developed a low-cost and simple method to prepare NC@CoS<sub>2</sub>@CNTs, exhibiting distinguished sodium storage performance (discharging capacity of 349.0 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> for 1000 cycles at 3.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, while Zhao et&nbsp;al. generated CoS<sub>2</sub>@C hollow nanocubes by carbon coating and sulfuration process, exhibiting exceptional cycling performance as the anode for SIBs (discharge capacity of 367.6 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> for 200 cycles at 5 A g<sup>−1</sup>) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0022" name="bbib0022" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0022"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>. On the flip side, it has been known that the formation of heterogeneous interfaces among active materials can induce charge redistribution, thereby facilitating ion/electron transport <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0025" name="bbib0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a><span>. For example, Sui et&nbsp;al. synthesized the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/heterojunctions" title="Learn more about heterojunction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heterojunction</a> of OFC@CoS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoO@rGO composite with sandwich structure, delivering 161 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> after 3500 cycles at 1 A g<sup>−1</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0025" name="bbib0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>. However, achieving high-redox activity and long-life anodes using a single metal sulfide is a challenging task.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0004">Herein, we have developed carbon-coated NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub> embedded porous nitrogen-doped carbon nanocubes (NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C) using Ni-Co Prussian blue analogues (Ni-Co PBAs) as the precursor. The NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C nanocubes synthesized in the present work possess several advantages as the high-performance anode for SIBs: (1) the distortion of the lattices and redistribution of charges at the heterogeneous interface between NiS<sub>2</sub> and CoS<sub>2</sub> promote the chemical reaction kinetics <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0028" name="bbib0028" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0028"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a><span><span>; (2) the RF-derived rigid carbon skeleton can effectively buffer the volume stress during high-temperature synthesis and prevent the material from structural collapse; (3) the doping of N into carbon materials can provide more <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/free-electron" title="Learn more about free electrons from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">free electrons</a> and improve the conductivity of the material; (4) and the highly </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/porous-carbon" title="Learn more about porous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous carbon</a> ensures the complete contact between the active material and the electrolyte and offers space for accommodating the volume change during charging/discharging. Building upon the aforementioned advantages, the as-synthesized NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C exhibits a high discharge capacity of 489.9 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> after 170 cycles at 1.0 A g<sup>−1</sup> and provides extraordinary long-cycle performance with a reversible capacity of 349.7 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> after 2000 cycles, with the CE close to 100.0%.</div></section><section id="sec0002"><h2 id="cesectitle0005" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Result and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0005"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;1</span></span></a> depicts the fabrication process of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C nanocubes. First of all, the Ni-Co-PBA is prepared by the well-organized complexation of Co[(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>3-</sup> anion and Ni<sup>2+</sup> cation with the aid of an aqueous solution of trisodium citrate dihydrate. From <strong>Fig. S1</strong><span>, the Ni-Co-PBA has been successfully synthesized with good <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a>, exhibiting a regular cube topography with a particle size of approximately 300 nm (</span><strong>Fig. S2</strong>). Then, in situ polymerization of resorcinol-formaldehyde (RF) is performed to realize a homogeneous coating on the surface of the nanocubes. In this case, the Ni-Co-PBA@RF possesses a relatively rough surface (<strong>Fig. S3</strong><span>). Through the sequential annealing of <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbonization" title="Learn more about carbonization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonization</a> and sulfuration, the Co and Ni atoms of the Ni-Co-PBA are well dispersed in the nanocubes and then vulcanized to obtain the NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0001"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr1.jpg" height="251" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0001"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (395KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (395KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0001"><p id="spara001"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Schematic diagram depicting the process for fabricating NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0006"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;2</span></span></a> displays the morphology and microstructure of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs.&nbsp;2</span></span></a>a and <strong>S4</strong>, the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C nanocomposite exhibits a regular cubic morphology with an edge length of approximately 300 nm and a rougher surface compared to the Ni-Co-PBA precursor. In contrast, the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC composite without the coating of carbon derived from RF undergoes severe aggregation and clear structural collapse due to the lack of protection by the rigid carbon skeleton (<strong>Fig. S5</strong><span>). The <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDX from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDX</a> clearly verifies the existence of Co, Ni, C, N and S elements (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;2</span></span></a>b). In addition, the elemental contents of Ni, Co, and S in the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C composites can be obtained by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis, which are 12.5%, 8.5%, and 23.7%, respectively (<strong>Table S1</strong>). From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs.&nbsp;2</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>d, the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub><span>@NC@C nanocubes present as a core-shell structure with the carbon layer as the shell with thickness of about 10 nm and the <a href="/topics/materials-science/porous-carbon" title="Learn more about porous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous carbon</a> cube derived from Ni-Co-PBA as the core in which NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub><span> <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a><span> are homogeneously embedded. This unique core-shell microstructure generally plays an momentous part in preserving the structure integrity of nanocomposites and facilitating the transport of electrons, favoring the <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage performance </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;2</span></span></a><span>e, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/high-resolution-transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a> image reveals the lattice fringes with the spacings of 0.283, 0.254, 0.318 and 0.278 nm, corresponding to the (200) and (210) crystal faces of NiS</span><sub>2</sub> and the (111) and (200) crystal faces of CoS<sub>2</sub>, respectively. Furthermore, the NiS<sub>2</sub> phase on the top and the CoS<sub>2</sub><span><span> phase on the bottom form a well-defined interface (indicated by the red line), confirming a mass of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/lattice-mismatch" title="Learn more about lattice mismatches from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice mismatches</a> and indicating the successful construction of the </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/heterojunctions" title="Learn more about heterojunction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heterojunction</a> between NiS</span><sub>2</sub> of CoS<sub>2</sub><span>. Moreover, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/selected-area-diffraction" title="Learn more about SAED from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAED</a> pattern of the NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;2</span></span></a>f. The white ring patterns are ascribed to the (220) and (222) crystal planes of NiS<sub>2</sub>, while the yellow ring patterns correspond to the (231), (321), and (221) crystal planes of CoS<sub>2</sub>, indicating the successful synthesis of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;2</span></span></a><span>g, Co, Ni, C, N and S elementals are uniformly distributed throughout the composite material, indicating that sulfide <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> are uniformly dispersed in N-doped porous carbon.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0002"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr2.jpg" height="434" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0002"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0002"><p id="spara002"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span><span>(a) Typical SEM image, (b) <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDX from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDX</a><span> spectrum, (c, d) TEM images, (e) <a href="/topics/materials-science/high-resolution-transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a> images (insets show that the lattice distance for 10 layers), (f) </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/selected-area-diffraction" title="Learn more about SAED from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAED</a> pattern and (g) elemental mapping of NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0007"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;3</span></span></a><span>a shows the <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> pattern of the NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C for characterizing the crystal structure. The diffraction peaks of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C correspond to cubic-phase CoS<sub>2</sub> (JCPDS Card No. 89-1492) and the cubic-phase NiS<sub>2</sub> (JCPDS Card No. 11-0099), and no other obvious impurity phases are detected, indicating that the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C has been successfully synthesized with high purity and good crystallinity. It is important to noted that CoS<sub>2</sub> and NiS<sub>2</sub><span> cannot be effectively distinguished by the resolution limits of XRD analysis because of their similar structures and <a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice constants from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice constants</a>. From </span><strong>Figs. S6</strong>, the diffraction peaks of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC conform to the standard cards of the cubic-phase CoS<sub>2</sub> and NiS<sub>2</sub>, indicating the successful synthesis of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub><span>@NC. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> has been used to characterize the carbonaceous components. From </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;3</span></span></a>b, the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C and NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC samples have two significant peaks, belonging to the characteristic D band and G band of carbon materials, respectively. Obviously, the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C (I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub><span>=1.07) possesses a significantly greater degree of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/graphitization" title="Learn more about graphitization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphitization</a> than NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC (I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub>=1.19), indicating that the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub><span>@NC@C has better <a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-transfer" title="Learn more about electron transport from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron transport</a> capacity </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0030" name="bbib0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0031" name="bbib0031" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0031"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0032" name="bbib0032" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0032"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0033" name="bbib0033" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0033"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs.&nbsp;3</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>d illustrate the isotherms of adsorption/desorption and the distributions of pore size. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;3</span></span></a>c, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C is 106.42 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>, much greater than that of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC (43.87 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>) owing to the existence of a large number of internal void spaces in the core-shell structure. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;3</span></span></a>d, both NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C and NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub><span>@NC exhibit a mesoporous structure. The high specific area and abundant <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a><span> promote the full penetration of electrolyte into the material and thus effectively improve the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> kinetics. The TG curves of the NiS</span></span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C and NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC are shown in <strong>Fig. S7</strong>. The initial weight loss at a temperature lower than 200 °C can be ascribed to the evaporation of adsorbed water, and the weight loss between 200 °C and 550 °C is contributed to the combustion of carbon, corresponding to a carbon content of about 51.0%. When the temperature exceeds 550°C, the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub> can be converted to NiCoO<sub>2</sub>, and the volatilisation of Ni<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> is inevitable during the heating process <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0034" name="bbib0034" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0034"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>. In addition, the theoretical capacity of NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C can be calculated as 617.68% according to <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#eqn0001" name="beqn0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="eqn0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">eqs.&nbsp;1</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#eqn0002" name="beqn0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="eqn0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0003"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr3.jpg" height="464" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0003"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (946KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (946KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0003"><p id="spara003"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <span>(a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> pattern of NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub><span>@NC@C, (b) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> of NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C and NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC, (c) N<sub>2</sub><span> adsorption-desorption isotherms and (d) <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-size-distribution" title="Learn more about pore size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore size distribution</a> of NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C and NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC, (e) XPS survey spectrum, high-resolution XPS spectra for (f) Co 2p, (g) Ni 2p, (h) S 2p and (i) C 1s of NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0008">The surface electronic states and chemical composition of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C are analyzed by XPS. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;3</span></span></a>e, the Co, N, C, S, Ni and O elements can be detected in NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C. Among them, the inevitable exposure of the materials to air before measurement may lead to the presence of O element in final sample, and since the peaks of Co and Ni in the full XPS spectra are too weak, Co and Ni are locally amplified and their relative contents calculated are shown in <strong>Fig. S8</strong>. The Co 2p spectrum is displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;3</span></span></a>f, which can be divided into two spin-orbit double peaks and two distinct satellite peaks. The satellite peaks of the Co 2p are located at 803.20 and 787.04 eV, which are associated with Co 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and Co 2p<sub>3/2</sub>, respectively, while the two spin-orbit double peaks are located at 799.33 eV/796.18 eV and 783.17 eV/779.18 eV, matching with the Co<sup>2+</sup>/Co<sup>3+</sup> of Co 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and Co 2p<sub>3/2</sub>, respectively. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;3</span></span></a>g, the double peak located at 857.22 eV/853.96 eV matches the Ni<sup>3+</sup>/Ni<sup>2+</sup> of Ni 2p<sub>3/2</sub>, and the other bimodal peaks located at 876.13 eV/871.30 eV belongs to Ni<sup>3+</sup>/Ni<sup>2+</sup> of Ni 2p<sub>1/2</sub>. In addition, the satellite peaks of Ni appear at 862.55 eV and 881.26 eV, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0035" name="bbib0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>. Clearly, the Co and Ni elements in the sample have two valence states of Co<sup>2+</sup>/Co<sup>3+</sup> and Ni<sup>2+</sup>/Ni<sup>3+</sup><span>, which provides extremely abundant <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> capacity for sodium storage. From </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;3</span></span></a>h, the peaks at 164.02, 165.62 and 169.26 eV in the S 2p spectrum match with S 2p<sub>1/2</sub>, S 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and satellite peaks, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0036" name="bbib0036" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0036"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;3</span></span></a>i, the C-C, C-N and C-O bands can be assigned to three peaks situated at 284.82, 285.9 and 287.1 eV, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0037" name="bbib0037" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0037"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>. Among them, the formation of C-N bond indicates the successful doping of N element. From <strong>Fig. S9</strong>, the N elements in the sample are pyridine nitrogen (397.99 eV), pyrrole nitrogen (399.76 eV) and graphite nitrogen (402.37 eV) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a><span>. The N-doping improves the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a><span> of the carbon matrix and provides a multitude of active sites, being beneficial to improve the reaction kinetics of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0038" name="bbib0038" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0038"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0009">The CV curves of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C nanocomposite at 0.1 mV s<sup>−1</sup> are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;4</span></span></a>a. The initial scanning process exhibits cathodic peaks at 1.12 V and 0.62 V, which can be ascribed to the transformation of NiS<sub>2</sub> to metallic Ni and Na<sub>2</sub>S (NiS<sub>2</sub>+Na→Ni+Na<sub>2</sub>S) and CoS<sub>2</sub> to metallic Co and Na<sub>2</sub>S (CoS<sub>2</sub>+Na→Co+Na<sub>2</sub><span>S) with the creation of a <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a><span> interfacial (SEI) film. In the initial anodic scan, two strong <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> peaks located at 1.78 V and 1.98 V indicate the conversion of metal Ni and Na</span></span><sub>2</sub>S to NiS<sub>2</sub> (Ni+Na<sub>2</sub>S→NiS<sub>2</sub>) and metal Co and Na<sub>2</sub>S to CoS<sub>2</sub> (Co+Na<sub>2</sub>S→CoS<sub>2</sub>), respectively. Besides, the positions of the reduction and oxidation peaks are almost the same during the subsequent cycles, indicating good reversibility of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C. To further investigate the detailed sodium storage mechanism during the discharge/charge process, the crystalline structures of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C composite at different stages are examined by the ex-situ XRD analysis. From <strong>Fig. S10</strong>, in the initial state, the characteristic peaks of NiS<sub>2</sub> and CoS<sub>2</sub> can be detected at 31.9° and 39.4°. As the voltage continues to discharge from 0.8 V to lower voltages, the peaks of NiS<sub>2</sub> and CoS<sub>2</sub> gradually diminish until disappear. Three new peaks appear during charging of the battery to 2.0 V, which are induced by the conversion reaction of CoS<sub>2</sub>/NiS<sub>2</sub><span> with <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a> to Na</span><sub>2</sub>S and metallic Co and Ni, respectively. The characteristic peaks of NiS<sub>2</sub> and CoS<sub>2</sub> reappear when charging is continued to 2.3 V. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;4</span></span></a>b displays the constant current charge-discharge curves of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C for the first five cycles at 1.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>. The initial charge and discharge capacities of the material are 807.9 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> and 920.6 mA h g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively, giving the initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 87.7%. Besides, in subsequent cycles, the reduction in capacity may be ascribed to the irreversible creation of the SEI film and disintegration of the electrolyte <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0039" name="bbib0039" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0039"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0040" name="bbib0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0041" name="bbib0041" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0041"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;4</span></span></a>c shows the cycling performance of the electrodes at 1.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>. Compared to the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC anode (99.7 mA h g<sup>−1</sup>), the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C provides a larger capacity of 489.9 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> after 170 cycles. To further explore the reasons for the excellent performance of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C, the microstructural changes of the electrode after 100 cycles as well as 170 cycles are observed by SEM (<strong>Fig. S11</strong>), and it can be seen that the electrode still basically maintains its nanocube morphology after a long period of cycling, which suggests that the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C has an excellent cycling stability. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;4</span></span></a>d displays the rate performance of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C. Obviously, the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C demonstrates better rate performance than the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC, delivering the discharge capacities of 501.9, 481.3, 456.0, 438.7, 418.7 and 387.7 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0 and 5.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively, and the discharge capacity of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C can be recovered to 500.2 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> when recovering from 5 A g<sup>−1</sup> to 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup>. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;4</span></span></a>e, distinct charging and discharging plateaus can still be observed even at 5.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>, manifesting a weak polarization for the material. Moreover, the rate performance of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C is comparable/superior to that of formerly reported sulfide anodes (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;4</span></span></a>f) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0042" name="bbib0042" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0042"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0043" name="bbib0043" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0043"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0044" name="bbib0044" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0044"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0045" name="bbib0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0046" name="bbib0046" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0046"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0047" name="bbib0047" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0047"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0048" name="bbib0048" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0048"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>]. From <strong>Figs. S12</strong> and <strong>S13</strong>, the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C electrode maintains prominent capacity of 545.9 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> after 50 cycles at 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup>, much larger than the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC (337.9 mA h g<sup>−1</sup>) and single-component CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C (220.4 mA h g<sup>−1</sup>), and the SEM and TEM tests of the electrode after cycling show that the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub><span>@NC@C has outstanding <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> (</span><strong>Fig. S14</strong>). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;4</span></span></a>g displays the cycling performance of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C and NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC at 5.0 A g<sup>−1</sup> after activation for 2 cycles at 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup>. Remarkably, the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C exhibits a high specific capacity of 349.7 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> with extremely good cycling stability even after 2000 cycles, with a CE close to 100.0%. From <strong>Table S2</strong>, the extraordinary cycling life of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C is achieved in this investigation. The exceptional sodium storage performance of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C is put down to its distinctive core-shell structure and the interfacial effect between NiS<sub>2</sub> and CoS<sub>2</sub>, which can availably quicken the diffusion rate of sodium ions within the host materials.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0004"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr4.jpg" height="424" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0004"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (915KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (915KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0004"><p id="spara004"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a) CV curves scanned at 0.1 m V s<sup>−1</sup>, and (b) Charge-discharge profiles of NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C cycling at 1.0 A g<sup>−1</sup> for the initial five cycles; (c) Cycling performance and coulombic efficiency at 1.0 A g<sup>−1</sup> and (d) rate performance of NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C and NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC; (e) Corresponding charge-discharge curves of NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C at diverse current densities; (f) Comparison of the rate capacity of NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub><span>@NC@C with recently reported anodes for <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>; and (g) Cycle life at 5.0 A g</span><sup>−1</sup> for NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C and NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0010">In order to investigate the reaction kinetics of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C, a kinetic analysis is performed based on CV curves at diverse sweep speeds. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;5</span></span></a>a, the CV curves of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C are basically similar without significant changes with sweep speed increasing from 0.2 mV s<sup>−1</sup> to 1.2 mV s<sup>−1</sup>, indicating that the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C electrode has excellent reversibility. Generally, the scan rate (<em>v</em>) and peak current (<em>i</em>) of the CV curves obey the following rules [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0049" name="bbib0049" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0049"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0050" name="bbib0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]:<span class="display"><span id="eqn0001" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="25.531ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -846.5 10992.5 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6C"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6F" x="278" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-67" x="779" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1446,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(735,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29"></use></g></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2848,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3904,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4334,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mtext id="MathJax-Element-6"><math><mrow is="true"><mtext is="true">log</mtext><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mi is="true">i</mi><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mrow is="true"></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">b</mi><mi is="true">l</mi><mi is="true">o</mi><mi is="true">g</mi><mrow is="true"></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr5.jpg" height="312" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (622KB)"><span
