u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0013468623014172-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0005"><p id="spara005"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. (a) CV curves of NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C; (b) Correlation between peak current and scan rate for NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C electrodes; (c) Contribution ratio of pseudocapacitive for NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C electrodes; (d) Capacitance contribution of NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C at 1.2 mV s<sup>−1</sup> as a percentage of total charge storage; (e) Calculated D<sub>Na+</sub> of NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C and NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC anodes; and (f) Nyquist plots of NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C and NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC before cycling.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0011">Where <em>b</em>-value denotes the sodium storage behavior. If the <em>b</em>-value approaches 1, the electrochemical reaction is primarily governed by the pseudocapacitance behavior, whereas the <em>b</em>-value in proximity to 0.5 indicates that the electrochemical reaction is mainly controlled by ion diffusion [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0051" name="bbib0051" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0051"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0052" name="bbib0052" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0052"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52</span></span></a>]. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;5</span></span></a>b, the <em>b</em> values of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C are 0.77, 0.86, 0.76, 0.45 and 0.94, respectively, reflecting that the electrochemical reactions of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C are primarily dominated by the pseudocapacitive behavior. Furthermore, the capacitance contribution in the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C electrode is analyzed based on the following equation <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0053" name="bbib0053" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0053"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>:<span class="display"><span id="eqn0003" class="formula"><span class="label">(3)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-7-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5338,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0012">The contributions from pseudocapacitance and ion diffusion-controlled storage behavior are represented by <em>k<sub>1</sub>v</em> and <em>k<sub>2</sub>v</em><sup>1/2</sup>, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0052" name="bbib0052" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0052"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0054" name="bbib0054" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0054"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">54</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;5</span></span></a>c shows that the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C electrode has large pseudocapacitance contributions, giving the capacitance contributions of 73.2%, 77.4%, 81.9%, 84.4% and 88.1% at 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.2 mV s<sup>−1</sup>, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs.&nbsp;5</span></span></a>d and <strong>S15</strong>), being beneficial for enhancing charge storage and cycle life of the material.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0013"><span>In order to further reveal the chemical reaction kinetics, the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> of Na</span><sup>+</sup> for the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C at 0.1 V-3 V is determined by the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT). The calculation of D<sub>Na+</sub> can be derived from the following equation <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0055" name="bbib0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0014">Where <em>n<sub>m</sub></em> and <em>V<sub>m</sub></em><span> denote the number of moles and <a href="/topics/materials-science/density-specific-gravity" title="Learn more about molar volume from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar volume</a> of the active material, respectively, </span><em>τ</em> is the relaxation time (min), and <em>ΔE<sub>s</sub></em> and <em>ΔE<sub>t</sub></em> are the voltage changes due to pulsed current and constant current, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0056" name="bbib0056" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0056"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;5</span></span></a>e, the D<sub>Na+</sub> values of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C electrode (8.04&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−12</sup>—1.04&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−9</sup>) are larger than those of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC (6.46&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−12</sup>—7.77&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−10</sup><span>) during discharging, resulting in excellent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> for the NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C anodes. Moreover, the electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of the electrodes are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;5</span></span></a>f. The Nyquist plots consist of a linear section at the low frequencies and semicircular at the high frequencies. Evidently, the charge transfer resistance of the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C (33.3 Ω) is smaller compared to the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC (56.6 Ω), exhibiting good electrochemical reaction kinetics.</div></section><section id="sec0003"><h2 id="cesectitle0006" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0015">In summary, we have synthesized the NiS<sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub><span>@NC@C nanocubes by in-situ <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbonization" title="Learn more about carbonization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonization</a> and subsequent sulphuration of RF-coated Ni-Co-based Prussian blue analogues. The RF-derived carbon shell acts as a rigid framework to ensure the structure integrity during high-temperature annealing, while the porous nitrogen-doped carbon nanocubes increase the electronic conductivity, promote abundant channels for ion/electron transfer and prevent the agglomeration of active material during chemical reaction. The generation of the heterogeneous interface between NiS</span><sub>2</sub> and CoS<sub>2</sub><span> induces the redistribution of electrons, fastening the chemical reaction kinetics. As a result, excellent <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> are achieved for the NiS</span><sub>2</sub>/CoS<sub>2</sub>@NC@C nanocubes: a high discharge capacity of 489.9 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> after 170 cycles at 1.0 A g<sup>−1</sup> with the ICE of 87.7% and the extraordinary long-cycle performance with the discharging capacity of 349.7 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> with the CE close to 100.0% at 5.0 A g<sup>−1</sup> even after 2000 cycles. This study provides a useful reference for developing advanced anodes with unique micromorphology and chemical composition.</div></section><section id="sec0003a"><h2 id="cesectitle0006a" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0015a"><strong>Ransha Deng:</strong> Investigation, Methodology, Conceptualization, Writing – original draft, Software. <strong>Peng Wang:</strong> Software, Visualization, Formal analysis. <strong>Yuxiang Chen:</strong> Data curation, Visualization. <strong>Qiaoji Zheng:</strong> Resources, Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision. <strong>Dunmin Lin:</strong> Resources, Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision.</div></section></div><section id="coi0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0007" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of Competing Interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0017">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0008" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0018">This work was supported by <span id="gs0001">Natural Science Foundation of Sichuan Province</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2022NSFSC0222</span></span></a>) and <span id="gs0002">Sichuan Science and Technology Program</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2023NSFSC0439</span></span></a>).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="sec0005"><h2 id="cesectitle9002" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix. class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="sbref0005"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">E. class="reference" id="sbref0055"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">J. Wang, Z. Xu, J.C. Eloi, M.M. Titirici, S.J. Eichhorn</div><div id="ref-id-sbref0055" class="title text-m">Ice-Templated, Sustainable Carbon Aerogels with Hierarchically Tailored Channels for Sodium-and Potassium-Ion Batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Adv. Funct. Mater., 32 (16) (2022), Article 2110862</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85122283129&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Ice-Templated%2C%20Sustainable%20Carbon%20Aerogels%20with%20Hierarchically%20Tailored%20Channels%20for%20Sodium-and%20Potassium-Ion%20Batteries&amp;publication_year=2022&amp;author=J.%20Wang&amp;author=Z.%20Xu&amp;author=J.C.%20Eloi&amp;author=M.M.%20Titirici&amp;author=S.J.%20Eichhorn" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bbib0056" id="ref-id-bib0056" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="sbref0056"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">X. Hu, X. Liu, K. Chen, G. Wang, H. Wang</div><div id="ref-id-sbref0056" class="title text-m">Core-shell MOF-derived N-doped yolk-shell carbon nanocages homogenously filled with ZnSe and CoSe<sub>2</sub> nanodots as excellent anode materials for lithium-and sodium-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">J. Mater. Chem. A, 7 (18) (2019), pp. 11016-11037</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1039/c9ta01999e" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref0056"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Crossref</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85065537434&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref0056"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Core-shell%20MOF-derived%20N-doped%20yolk-shell%20carbon%20nanocages%20homogenously%20filled%20with%20ZnSe%20and%20CoSe2%20nanodots%20as%20excellent%20anode%20materials%20for%20lithium-and%20sodium-ion%20batteries&amp;publication_year=2019&amp;author=X.%20Hu&amp;author=X.%20Liu&amp;author=K.%20Chen&amp;author=G.%20Wang&amp;author=H.%20Wang" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref0056"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (9)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979725006927"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Bimetallic sulfide Fe&lt;inf&gt;5&lt;/inf&gt;Ni&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;S&lt;inf&gt;8&lt;/inf&gt; nanoparticles modified N/S co-doped carbon nanofibers as anode materials for high-performance sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Transition metal sulfides (TMSs) have garnered significant attention owing to high theoretical capacities, favorable environmental compatibility, abundant natural resources, and suitable discharge/charge voltage platform in the field of anode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, the sluggish reaction rates and significant volume alteration during the process of sodiation/desodiation restrict the practical application of TMSs for SIBs. Herein, a novel bimetallic sulfide Fe<sub>5</sub>Ni<sub>4</sub>S<sub>8</sub> nanoparticles modified nitrogen/sulfur co-doped carbon nanofibers (NSCFs) composite is successfully synthesized using a straightforward electrostatic spinning and sulfurization treatment. As an anode material for SIBs, Fe<sub>5</sub>Ni<sub>4</sub>S<sub>8</sub>/NSCFs exhibits a high reversible specific capacity of 686.34&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1&nbsp;A/g and a capacity of 607.26&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> after 120 cycles at 1.0&nbsp;A/g with a capacity retention rate of 96.9&nbsp;%. Even at 10.0&nbsp;A/g, it still maintains a capacity of 481.14&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 800 cycles, indicating an excellent electrochemical energy storage performance. Density functional theory calculations demonstrate that the Fe<sub>5</sub>Ni<sub>4</sub>S<sub>8</sub> exhibits enhanced binding with NSCFs, promoted electron transfers, improved Na<sup>+</sup> adsorption ability, and decreased Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion barrier energy compared to those of monometallic sulfide FeS. Additionally, the three-dimensional network skeleton of NSCFs can effectively enhance the electrical conductivity and relieve the volume change during the discharge and charge process. The innovative multicomponent design and nanostructural configuration provide a promising strategy to develop high-performance anode materials based on bimetallic sulfide for SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0013468625004827"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">N, S Co-doped carbon-enhanced FeS&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; yolk–shell structure: Overcoming volume expansion and polysulfide shuttle issues in sodium-ion battery anodes</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Electrochimica Acta</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara009">Pyrite FeS<sub>2</sub> has the advantages of high theoretical capacity, environmental friendliness, and low cost as an anode material for sodium-ion batteries, but it suffers from large volume expansion during cycling as well as the problem of polysulfide shuttling, which seriously affects its cycling stability and rate performance. Therefore, in this paper, a yolk–shell FeS<sub>2</sub>@NSC composite was synthesized by using Prussian blue (PB) as a precursor through dopamine coating and subsequent carbonization and vulcanization processes. The as-prepared FeS<sub>2</sub>@NSC structure not only has sufficient internal space to mitigate the volume expansion but also effectively blocks the shuttling of polysulfides through the physical barrier and chemical adsorption of the N, S co-doped carbon layer, which effectively improves the cycling stability and rate performance of the electrode. As a result, it exhibits a high specific capacity of 939 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> after 200 cycles at 0.5 A <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> with a superior rate capability of 575.5 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> at 10 A <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup>. Most impressively, a stable capacity of 592 mAh <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup> can still be retained even after 800 cycles at 5 A <em>g</em><sup>−1</sup>. The structure provides an idea for designing high-performance anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0013468624015706"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Enhanced sodium storage in MXene transition metal chalcogenides anode through dual molten salt etching</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Electrochimica Acta</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara007">Referred to as potential options for anodes in sodium-ion batteries, transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) exhibit unique electronic and structural characteristics. However, the limited electrical conductivity inherent in them poses a hindrance to electron transport, while their tendency to undergo volumetric expansion during cycling exacerbates structural instability, thereby imposing constraints on practical applications. Herein, a dual molten salt etching strategy followed by a sulfidation-selenidation process was employed to anchor multi-component sulfides FeS<sub>2</sub>/NiS and FeSe/NiSe onto conductive Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub>T<sub>x</sub> MXene, achieving superior sodium storage performance. Owing to the enhanced Na⁺ and faster kinetics of electronic transport, mechanical strain is effectively reduced, and strong covalent interactions are formed at the interface, significant enhancement in the cycling stability is observed for the anodes of Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub>T<sub>x</sub>@FeS<sub>2</sub>/NiS and Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub>T<sub>x</sub>@FeSe/NiSe (with specific capacities of 309.4 and 162.6 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively, after 1000 cycles at 5 A g<sup>−1</sup>, with a former retention capacity rate that can reach as high as 87.8 %) and exceptional rate performance (252.1 and 207.8 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively, at 8 A g<sup>−1</sup>). Furthermore, full cells assembled by pairing Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub>T<sub>x</sub>@FeS<sub>2</sub>/NiS and Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub>T<sub>x</sub>@FeSe/NiSe with Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes also demonstrate excellent cycling performance, with both configurations achieving up to 500 cycles. The suggested approach enables efficient utilization of byproducts from Lewis acidic etching, expanding possibilities for synthesizing high-performance anodes in sodium-ion batteries consisting of MXene and TMCs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724005976"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Heterogeneous engineering and carbon confinement strategy to synergistically boost the sodium storage performance of transition metal selenides</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">From Fig. 2f, the RF-derived carbon skeleton of the CoSe2/FeSe2@NC@C can be visually observed with a thickness of 40 – 50 nm. The carbon framework effectively prevents the material from collapsing and pulverizing during the cycle, protecting the internal active material[34,35]. In the HRTEM images (Fig. 2g and Fig. 2h) of the CoSe2/FeSe2@NC@C, the (1 0 1) and (1 2 0) planes of FeSe2 and (1 2 0) and (1 1 1) planes of CoSe2 are clearly visible with lattices of 0.287, 0.248, 0.249 and 0.261 nm, respectively.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Transition metal selenides (TMSs) stand out as a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) owing to their natural resources and exceptional sodium storage capacity. Despite these advantages, their practical application faces challenges, such as poor electronic conductivity, sluggish reaction kinetics and severe agglomeration during electrochemical reactions, hindering their effective utilization. Herein, the dual-carbon-confined CoSe<sub>2</sub>/FeSe<sub>2</sub>@NC@C nanocubes with heterogeneous structure are synthesized using ZIF-67 as the template by ion exchange, resorcin-formaldehyde (RF) coating, and subsequent <em>in situ</em> carbonization and selenidation. The <em>N</em>-doped porous carbon promotes rapid electrolyte penetration and minimizes the agglomeration of active materials during charging and discharging, while the RF-derived carbon framework reduces the cycling stress and keeps the integrity of the material structure. More importantly, the built-in electric field at the heterogeneous boundary layer drives electron redistribution, optimizing the electronic structure and enhancing the reaction kinetics of the anode material. Based on this, the nanocubes of CoSe<sub>2</sub>/FeSe<sub>2</sub>@NC@C exhibits superb sodium storage performance, delivering a high discharge capacity of 512.6&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.5 A g<sup>−1</sup> after 150 cycles and giving a discharge capacity of 298.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 10 A g<sup>−1</sup> with a CE close to 100.0&nbsp;% even after 1000 cycles. This study proposes a viable method to synthesize advanced anodes for SIBs by a synergy effect of heterogeneous interfacial engineering and a carbon confinement strategy.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1007/s40820-024-01517-y" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Prussian Blue Analogue-Templated Nanocomposites for Alkali-Ion Batteries: Progress and Perspective</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2025, Nano-Micro Letters</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acsami.4c09171" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Anion Doping and Dual-Carbon Confinement Strategies to Synergistically Boost the Sodium Storage Performance of Cobalt-Based Sulfides</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, ACS Applied Materials and Interfaces</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li></ul><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-secondary large-alternative button-alternative-icon-left" href="http://www.scopus.com/scopus/inward/citedby.url?partnerID=10&amp;rel=3.0.0&amp;eid=2-s2.0-85171990280&amp;md5=ce5139603ad3e6b0b071506257b28421" target="_blank" id="citing-articles-view-all-btn"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">View all citing articles on Scopus</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></a></div></div></section></div><a class="anchor abstract-link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/abs/pii/S0013468623014172"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View Abstract</span></span></a><div class="Copyright"><span class="copyright-line">© 2023 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.</span></div></article><div class="u-display-block-from-md col-lg-6 col-md-8 pad-right u-padding-s-top"><aside class="RelatedContent u-clr-grey8" aria-label="Related data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=recommended-articles:type=close"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text"><h2 class="section-title u-h4"><span class="related-content-panel-title-text">Recommended articles</span></h2></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 class="RelatedContentPanelItem u-display-block"><div class="sub-heading u-padding-xs-bottom"><h3 class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article0-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S001346862100815X" title="SnS2-CoS2@C nanocubes as high initial coulombic efficiency and long-life anodes for sodium-ion batteries"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>SnS<sub>2</sub>-CoS<sub>2</sub>@C nanocubes as high initial coulombic aria-describedby="recommended-articles-article0-title"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z" stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path d="M.167 2.592H22.39V9.72H.166z" fill="#da0000"></path><path fill="#fff9f9" d="M5.97 3.638h1.62c1.053 0 1.483.677 1.488 1.564.008.96-.6     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
      },
    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
